Hello there, optometry student here. I know this video was made awhile ago, I just wanted to say that you did a great job teaching how pinholes work! One correction I wanted to make was that you mentioned pinholing works no matter how blurry your vision is, however this is only true if the source of blurry vision is refractive in nature (meaning it can be corrected using lenses). There are many ocular conditions that damage the cornea or retina and therefore pinholing will not help those people see more clearly. Cheers!

I came to some money in summer 2013 and decided to get new glasses as I had trouble seeing clearly with my old ones. The optician I had used long time and still use checked my eyes and told me that he can not get any good readings for my left eye and told me to go and see an eye doctor. So I called a local hospital and got an appointment. For reference I was 52 years old then. I went to the eye doctor who was lovely woman in her thirties. She checked my left eye and tried this and that and nothing worked. Then she went to her computer and I could get the gist that she was searching through various medical databases what to try. I could hear the lightbulb over her head when she came to me and took everything off from the front of my left eye and then told me that she had calculated all the correction my left eye needs without the axial correction and put those lenses in front of my left eye. Then she said that lets try this and put a pinhole lens in there and I could read the smallest letters from the table.

She told that the lens in my left eye is deformed and has multiple foci and that the problem was that these things are normally found when people are at the age 25 or so. And I asked that was that the time when I told the optician that my left eye sees double image and the reply was that I talk nonesense and she said yes. So she arranged me to have the lens replaced and told me that the luck in this situation was that the operation was much better now than 25 years ago.

So on 23rd of October 2013 I was asked to come to premiliary checking in our local university hospital. The eye doctor asked me that he thought that giving me a minus one lens was best option as I've been nearsighted my whole life in which I said that I'd prefer that too as an electrician I need to see clearly at close. When I went to get the time for the operation the nurse asked me if I can come the next day as there was a free space in line because of a cancellation. I said that it's fine. So on 24th of October 2013 I got a new lens into my left eye.

In the after checking the eye doctor told that he thinks that right eye's lens has to be replaced also because the imbalace between the eyes and asked if I'm ok with that and I said yes. So 18th of March 2014 my right eye got a new lens.

Now I use glases at home only when watching the television. I use them outside but if I forget them it's not a big deal. I'm still wondering how well I can see now and I'm very gratefull that the cataracts operations have been perfected so that these kinds of miracles are available to us.

I learned this secret many years ago as a child, quite by accident.  Some friends of mine would take bottle caps, poke a small hole in them with a nail, then paint them silver. We would then use them as one would use a monocle.  It looked "cool".  I had always been severely nearsighted.  But when I took my glasses off and used two of our "monocles" I could see fine.  Since learning this trick, I have used it numerous times when awaking and not knowing where my glasses were.  It's the only way I can see to find my glasses.

Wait, this is not all correct.
The pin hole effect turns the image 180 degrees, while here it doesn’t. It can surely limit the thickness of light ray from the same source, which is the same when you only open your eyelids a tiny gap.
The true reason is that light, as a form of WAVE, it defract(if it’s the right word) around edges of objects. Veritasium channel proved “brightest part of shadow is its center” with this. Light waves defract around your fingers, spread out after leaving the hole, make the hole works like a concave lens.
Just put one straight finger in front of your eye, see how the farther graphics bend.

Can you please explain what "LOVE" is @minutephysics

What is a picture frame?

In the case of the raster glasses, instead of the optical correction glasses, curved dark plastic discs are incorporated, in which many small holes are punched. They are reminiscent of the compound eye of a fly.
In fact, an image seen through the frame glasses consists of many, very sharply focusable individual segments, which assemble the brain to an overall picture with increasing mobility of the eye muscles, so that after a short time the dot pattern is barely perceived.
In the case of the raster goggles, the incident light beam is now bundled and aligned in front of the eye through the perforation of the goggles and thereby hits directly on the center of the retina, in the place of the sharpest vision. The functionality of the grid glasses is comparable to the principle of the pinhole of a camera. Due to the almost sharp image on the retina, the brain is animated to use the eye muscles for the rest of the focus. At the same time, the brain sets the eye muscle in motion for optimal focusing, which has the added benefit of a permanent training effect and a relaxed feel
In the case of the raster goggles, the incident light beam is now bundled and aligned in front of the eye through the perforation of the goggles, thereby striking directly at the center of the retina, at the point of the sharpest vision. The functionality of the grid glasses is comparable to the principle of the pinhole of a camera. Due to the almost sharp image on the retina, the brain is animated to use the eye muscles for the rest of the focus. At the same time, the brain sets the eye muscle in motion for optimal focusing, providing the added benefit of a permanent training effect and encouraging relaxed, natural vision.
The regular training with the grid glasses is a holistic method for relaxed, natural vision. It causes a natural calming of the retina and can positively affect the entire eye organism, especially perception, color perception and light tolerance of your eyes.

The frame glasses can be used universally depending on personal goals. As prevention and general relaxation of the eyes, to improve existing visual disturbances z. B. Presbyopia and for the correction of short-sightedness and hyperopia. Important is the daily wearing of 10 to 20 minutes. Basically you can wear the grid glasses as often and as long as you like. They do not hurt your eyes under any circumstances. The well-being and relaxation of your eyes should rather be a measure of the wearing time of the grid glasses.

Jupiter w/o a telescope: During a solar eclipse, partial or total, you can see crescents on the ground formed by spacing of leaves on a tree or any small opening that the light falls on. Years ago during a partial eclipse I noticed this and formed the small hole as Henry explains in the video but focused the light on the ground with my hand (warning Never look at a solar eclipse directly with your eyes except through welder's glass or on a background). Viola! I formed a crescent of an eclipse on the ground and on a white board with just my hand. I forgot about this little trick until tonight when I walked outside. I remembered watching Henry's video on the trick and wondered if I could see the disk of a planet. Jupiter is in the sky most of the night, since it is very bright and easily located, so I made the pinhole with my hand, located Jupiter and I could see a tiny but discernible disk. Skeptical that I really could see a disk I tried the technique with Sirius, a star located near Orion, but could not focus the light, that is, it just remained blurry. Try it yourself and let the MP community know your results .

this is why that theory about eye size is bullshit. it's almost certainly lens quality and manipulation. you can even tell when you try to focus on things near and far; your eye adjusts like a camera. the problem is nowadays we spend so much time inside looking at close-up things that our lenses forget how to see Faraway. and instead of exercising lenses, we just get glasses which makes things worse overtime. if you learn to do the right exercises, over time your vision can improve several numbers. and if you're still good vision, then keep going outside a lot and look as far as you can as often as you can.

But you make the assumption (more logical than believeing in self generated miracles), that there is a reason for this lense. It is more logically that the goal of this lense is related to the fact that the eye needed MORE LIGHT than the one passwing by a pinpoint hole, so a larger hole, but for using this light, we need to concentrate what comes from the same point to the same point. (f = R/2) f = focal length, R = Radius of Curvature
(1/f = 1/do + 1/di)
(M = ho/hi) M = magnification
(D = 1/f) D = Diopter

Too bad this does little to fix astigmatism. In myopia or hyperopia, your lens still has a uniform curvature in all meridians (it's just the wrong curvature), but in astigmatism the curvature is not constant. Even a slight deviation in angle of incidence of light onto your lens will cause a disproportionately large (or small) amount of difference between the diffraction of two rays; meaning your vision will still be blurry.

Let me share more information about this. I found this trick by myself a few months ago, but I took it one step forward.
I've always had a good sight, so when one day I looked out the window and noticed objects far away were blur in my left eye I got a little bit nervous about it and tried different things (starting by rubbing my eyes). I like photography so I thought about the depth of field in a pinhole thing and it worked, but here comes the best. While looking to far objects through the pinhole, I started opening it slowly while trying to maintain the focus. If I do it slowly enough, I can get my fingers fully extended and the sharpness on far objects stays. So I'm guessing in my case is a muscle thing. My eyes are getting too used to short sight (too many hours of computer screen maybe?) and the muscles are fixed for many hours, but with this trick I "force" them to relax. I even have a little sensation in the eye in the process (although it could be psychological), but the more I do it, the more my sight gets better.
Of course that is why eye doctors recomend resting the eyes by looking at the horizon.
Cheers!

My family and I were coming from church and my mother had a really netty scarf and I put it against my face for some reason (something just told me; God told me) and I saw so clearly I cried. Everything was so beautiful and crisp. I have glasses now and it just hurts my eyes and everything is so... weird. It's different. Now I know why I was able to see everything so wonderful that day. My eyes are just relying on my glasses to do its work and my glasses aren't helping it get better.

When I close my eyes to go to bed, it's completely dark but I see flashes of light in my vision. I'm not really sure if I see it or not, sometimes I think I'm dreaming or hallucinating but I still tell the optometrist and he says there's nothing he can do for it. I think it is his job to know. I just think he's inexperienced because he's young.

Every morning, the sun hits my face and I close my eyes and my eyes find the light and when I open them everything is as crisp as I saw it that day. I think the sun helps it. And before you say anything about the sun damaging my eyes, I never look directly at the sun. I just love the sun in my face but I think maybe this is the reason I see those flashes of light in my vision before bed.

Well, there you have it. The life of my eyes... I don't even know what to do anymore. I don't want to be blind. I want to see what I could before I become blind so I read a lot and stare at everything, daydreaming. Maybe my eyes will get better when in 21 and have that laser eye surgery... LOL. Only seven more years to go. Pray for me.

I figured this out when I was about 9 years old and have been perfecting it ever since so I share with you these refinements. First is instead of the way shown here just use the diamond shaped hole you make as you place your fingers in the position you hold a pencil in your fingers but without the pencil, now you have a hole that works much better and to focus just adjust the size of the hole while the back of your hand is laid against your nose. Second approach is better in the sense that you widen your field of view and attract less attention to the oddity when in public, which is to place your index or pointing finger placed on your nose horizontally. Your aim is to put the text in line with the top side of your index finger which will give you a clear view from left to right and is clearly better when reading text or print at a distance. Feel funny about doing it in public? Having done this since about the age of 10 I have since come up with some responses. If your with a friend who is the type that may be likely to tease about it then make sure to use the finger that points in their direction and say something like "I was just thinking if I was wearing a (I'm with stupid shirt) which way the finger should point." Or if your with someone deserving of a compliment then use the moment to say, "I'm sorry I was just thinking of who the (sexiest, coolest, nicest etc.) person in the room was and well... then raise your eyebrows and tilt your head to the side. If you don't agree or have a question let me know.

1) Create a v-shape with your middle and index finger
2) Place both fingers on either sides of your eye
3) Squeeze inwards a little and your vision will become clear again, temporarily.

If you want to improve your sight naturally and in a cheap and simple way - buy simple pinhole glasses (they cost like 5 to 20 dollars on e-bay). Wearing them for at least 20 minutes a day will give ou significant results. PLUS NEVER strain to see, rest well, eat well, try to remove the stress from your life as these all conditions affect vision. If you want to learn more, buy a book "Relearning to See: Improve Your Eyesight Naturally!" by Thomas R.Quackenbush. Good luck!

FOR PEOPLE WHO DON'T HAVE GLASSES

1. Close one eye
2. focus the open eye so that you can see your nose kinda

Using a pinhole is a simple test Opticians have been using for years to determine if poor vision is a result of an optical defect or a medical condition. If vision improves with a pinhole, then it's going to be optical and can be improved with lenses, if vision does not improve, then there is another cause. Using a pinhole is just the same as using a smaller aperture (higher f number) on a camera to get a deeper depth of field. It's no great breakthrough, so why make so much of it on this video!!!

Just one note: imho the muscles in the eye are not squeezing the lens to focus in the near, they are stretching or flattening the lens to focus in the distance.
Young people have flexible thick lenses, they become flat and unflexible from stretching at older ages, loosing the ability to get thick.
Therefore "reading glasses" for elder, farsighted people are convex (thick) while glasses for shortsighted people are concave.

Back in the day, my only camera was a "pinhole" camera, which used plain B&W paper inside an old checkbook box. A piece of cardboard was the shutter.

Yes, a box with a ~0.5mm pinhole on one side. and a "holder" for paper inside.

It took some trial and error to get the right exposure time (usually 30 seconds or so), but you could take some neat B&W negatives. No light projectors, just some chemicals to develop & fix the paper, and you had a good image. In negative.

Then, to get a "positive", just press a second piece of photopaper below it (Between glass plates worked) and expose to the sun, or a lamp, for a second or so (again, trial and error) and you had a fair "positive".

Again, just using a pinhole

Hello there,
I really enjoy your videos about physics in a few minutes.
One little correction about anatomy though: the lens in the human eye is not pinched by muscles but it is elastic in itself. There is a circular muscle around the lens which is connected to it by small ligaments. When this muscle contracts the ligaments are relaxed and the lens becomes thicker (and stronger) by its own elasticity. When the muscle is relaxed, these same ligaments pull the lens in flatter shape which results in less strength. The elasticity is also the reason why people have to hold everything farther from their eyes when they become older. The lens loses this elasticity over time.
Keep going with your videos, I love them. :)

This is exactly what "pin hole readers" are about. These have been advertised in the back of Phantom comics since the seventies I recall and are now to be found around the net being advertised for a dollar or two a pair. I bought a couple of pairs and have them around for emergencies but most important is that if you use them more then they actually improve your vision, in contrast to traditional corrective lenses. It's got to do with muscles which either are made to work harder or given a crutch instead. They are hard work though. I feel that he implies that the only reason we need glasses is because our lens has become damaged. More often than not, we need glasses to refocus light to our retina because our eye is not the proper (matching) length for our lens. It's only after about the age of 45-50 that presbyopia takes hold and our lens cannot accommodate as well any longer. This is when we have to wear glasses for a human lens issue.

This works well with plenty of illumination, but not in low-light conditions.

That's why people who need glasses need them more urgently at night. In bright light, the pupil of your eye contracts, to reduce the amount of light entering your eye. That produces a pinhole camera effect, bringing things into sharper focus even when the eyes' lenses do not focus correctly due to myopia, presbyopia, hyperopia, or astigmatism. It's why many people with eye problems can see adequately to drive in the daytime, but not at night.

Sorry, but I used this as a basic visualisation tool for 'Depth of Field' with my photography students for ten years. Looking through a hole smaller than your iris is why we 'screw-up' our eyes to form a false iris from the eyelids.
 It's also why seeing an illuminated bus number late at night is harder, because the ambient 'darkness' opens the iris and reduces depth of field.

fwiw, this also speaks to why your vision is fuzzy at night.  Since there is less light at night, your pupils open up to let in more light.  Since your pupils are now larger, they have less focusing power, and thus fuzzy vision.  It is the same principle as what's shown in this video.

It's also why sunglasses reduce visual acuity in those of us with imperfect vision. Bright sun causes the pupil to constrict, increasing depth of field and improving vision in the marginally out of focus areas. Wear sunglasses and your pupils dilate, reducing depth of field and making poor focus more obvious.

Did you all know the most common cause of needing glasses is the atrophy of the muscles which allow you to change the shape of the lens in your eye as shown in the video? By exercising those muscles, you can slowly strengthen these muscles and improve your eyesight. A couple minutes a day for a year and you will see an improvement, try it out!

Focus on your screen and then start to focus past it and when you feel a strain or discomfort, try to hold it there for a few seconds. Then draw your focus back to the monitor and keep drawing it in toward your face. Keep going until you feel the strain and hold it. Lastly move your eyes around in all directions like look as far left as you can, again until you feel a strain then hold it, then look up until you feel the strain, etc... But look in all directions do a 360. This is the eye workout, strong eyes = good vision. Try it out and let me know what y'all think.

I discovered this myself when I was maybe 8 years old and I used it a couple times when needed and more just for fun. Galileo did it with his telescopes but it actually had a negative effect since it reduced the aperture and thus photons entering his lens and it also narrowed his field of view. He did it though because, most likely, he used it at other times due to poor vision. The camera obscura (hidden room in Italian) was the precursor to modern photography and you can still make a pin hole camera today for a few dollars. It's a neat project :)
The hole they show them making, though, isn't small enough. You've got to get down to pinprick size. With my hand, anyways, that takes two hands.

Eyelashes work very well too to compensate for the lack of a lens. Simply lower your eyelid to where it brings things into focus. This likely only works for people with positive dioptry on their glasses, but works anywhere from +1 to +11 and beyond. The former being common, the latter being what people with no natural lens tend to have (aphakia).

Btw, on a very sunny day, cover up all your windows so they let NO light in. Then tear a "pinhole" (1-2cm diameter) in the center of your window and you get a projection of the outside world on your walls.

Fun, but not exactly correct: muscles do not squeeze lens, it is squeezing an aye. Transversal muscles make aye longer, lateral muscles make it shorter. By that mechanic focus point of a lens is constant, but moving a projection field, and by that we get aye focused on short or long-distaced objects. And from that, we can correct our vision by training that muscles, without glasses-wheelchair

wow, one more cool thing to try out:
use your fingers to create a pinhole, then focus near your fingers, and then focus on a distant object again.
The object (or area) you are focusing on in the distant will stay pretty much the same sharpness, but will move away and get closer as if you're using a zoom function with your eyes!

If your lens is damaged an pin hole wont help you - talk to cataract patients.  If you have a retinal detachment, a pin hole wont help you, if you have glaucoma, a pin hole wont help you, if you have a whole host of degenerative diseases more common than you think ie Retinitis pigmentosa, a pin hole wont help you.  If you have fuch's heterochromia, a pin hole wont help you, if you have a Central Retinal Artery/Vein occlusion, Coat's disease,  choroidal melanoma, Central serous retinopathy, Diabetic Retinopathy, Hypertensive Retinopathy, Macular Degeneration,  Macular hole, Posterior vitreous detachment, guess what, a pin hole wont help you.  See your local Optometrist or Ophthalmologist regularly.

Dear author: Most people who require glasses don't need them because their lenses don't move well enough to accomodate. Instead, they need them because their eyes are either too long or short (ie., axial length of the eyeball), or their corneas are too curved or flat. These lead to nearsightedness (myopia) or farsightedness (hyperopia).

As you get older, you DO lose flexibility of the lens, which results in difficulty focusing on close objects. This is termed presbyopia, and is what leads to you getting reading glasses, or (if you already wear corrective lenses for myopia) bifocals.

This trick will only work if you have blurry vision due to refractive issues (which are the most common) - these have to do with the way the light is focused on the retina by the cornea and lens.

For other things causing vision problems (diabetic retinopathy, macular degeneration, glaucoma, etc) this trick won't work.

I had discovered this effect years ago but with a bit different results. By doing this experiment with the tiny hole I tried to make my eyes see blurry but instead of managing having a blurry image I saw everything shrinking (or moving away). I guess the same principles work here. I just wanted to share this with you. Nice video!

The part about our eye muscles squeezing the lens is incorrect.

The lens is suspended in the middle of a circular muscle, attached by many fibers. For distance viewing, the muscle is relaxed, and the fibers pull outward on the lens - it's continually under tension. For near viewing, the circular muscle contracts, loosens up the tension on the fibers; as a result, the lens is no longer being stretched outwards, and becomes thicker.

Other than that, this is a great video - well done.

Personally, I prefer not having glasses and/or contact lenses. Not seeing everything makes me process less information and allows myself to focus morose on my internal world more than anything.
No more looking both ways down the park and saying to myself "Two people down to the right, three to the left. None where I'm at.". Yeah I squint because before this year I had glasses most my life and it's a habit worth breaking.
Sure, I could be delusional. But it beats relying on my parents to pay for something. Beause whenever I do buy something I am always asked "How did you buy this if you can't afford it?". (Such is the life of a musician).
Plus, if I ever do want to see something I just bring it closer and/or consume Either Carrots/Vitamin A or Psilocybin mushrooms. Both of which enhance vision (from my experience). Although I don't see myself as an active 'hunter and gatherer' (which psilocybin may promote with the visual enhancement). But hey, there's also marijuana boosting visuals from prior Psilocybin doses.
Sure I may be getting off topic but at this point self-expression is as contagious as kicking a ball in the sun. Did I mention how horrible it is to rely on glasses & contacts?
First of all, you can't lay down with either of these. The glasses just would break in that circumstance and the contacts would have to be taken out before sleeping with them in. It's bad enough having to form the habbit of brushing teeth and washing of the face before resting.
Plus, do you really want to analyze body language in midst of communication and easily forget the flow of concentration? Perfect vision causes headaches. If I want to see everything at all times I'll await for evolution in that case to form it naturally, thank you very much! (Coming from someone whom wore Glasses/Contacts from 2004-2014).
Another note you might say is "Well what if when you're driving?! you have to see everything from the pedestrians to the street lights to the other cars turning in your lanes through the mirror"
To which I would argue "Bitch, get in the car with me and see for yourself that driving doesn't have to involve stories of adrenaline, fight or flight, other driver analyzation, honking the horn after being cut off", etc, etc.
Not to mention the egotistical mindfucking this video presents with it's language of "Physics" of which only men in their 30's may understand or have the patience to portray.
Eh well this pretty much just about does it when it comes to the topic of Vision and contacts/glasses and my experience of it within the past 10 years and what I've learned from it and how I choose to adapt to it from here on out.

Actually, most of the optical power in your eyes is from the air/cornea interface, and the lens is more of a tuning nob.

Since our eyes use refraction to focus light, they depend on curved boundaries between materials with different indexes of refraction to bend light. The ratio of indexes of refraction determines how a light ray coming in at a given angle will change course. Since the Air/cornea interface has a ratio close to 1:1.38, it can bend light a lot with fairly modest curvature. But the interfaces around the lens have a ratio of 1.34:1.38, which is very close to 1:1! It can't actually bend light very much, even with extreme curvature!

Check it out for yourself at http://hyperphysics.phy-astr.gsu.edu/hbase/vision/eyescal.html, it lays the whole thing out with some nice diagrams.

There are "Glasses" called Pinhole glasses which use this effect, in third world countries they create a net out of strings attached to a frame and use this as glasses.
